editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A comedy. As it hath been presented at the phoenix in drury-lane. The author James Shirley, servant to her majesty.
Et spes, et ratio studiorum, in caesare tantum.
Printed by B. Alsop. and T. faucet. for William Cooke, and are to be sold at his shop near Furnivals-inn gate, in Holborn. 1633.

list.item: Philenzo lover of Eugenia, under the disguise and name of Rollyardo.
Bonamico a mountebank, or decayed artist.

div.head: To master William Prinne, utter-barrister of Lincolns-inn.
div.p:
The fame of your candour and innocent love to learning, especially to that musical part of humane knowledge poetry, and in particular to that which concerns the stage and scene (Your self as I hear, having lately written a tragedy) doth justly challenge from me this dedication. I had an early desire to congratulate your happy retirement, but no poem could tempt me with so fair a circumstance as this in the title, wherein I take some delight to think (Not without imitation of yourself) who have ingeniously fancied such elegant and apposite names, for your own compositions, as health's sickness, the unloveliness of love ▪ locks, etc.) how aptly I may present you at this time, with the bird in a cage. A comedy, which wanteth I must confess, much of that ornament, which the stage and action lent it, for it comprehending also another play or interlude, personated by ladies, I must refer to your imagination, the music, the songs, the dancing, and other varieties, which I know would have pleased you infinitely in the presentment. I was the rather inclined to make this oblation, that posterity might read you a patron to the Muses, and one that durst in such a critical age ▪ bind up the wounds which ignorance had printed upon wit and the professors: proceed (Inimitable Maecenas)
and having such convenient leisure, and an Pegasus, I mean your prose (Which scorneth the road of common sense, and despiseth any style in his way) travel still in the pursuit of new discoveries, which you may publish if you please, in your next book of digressions. If you do not happen presently to convert the organs, you may in time confuse the steeple, and bring every parish to one bell. —

This is all I have to say at this time, and my own occasions not permitting my personal attendance, I have entreated a gentleman to deliver this testimony of my service, many faults have escaped the press, which your judgement will no sooner find, than your mercy correct, by which you shall teach others a charity to your own volumes, though they be all errata. If you continue where you are, you will every day enlarge your fame, and beside the engagement of other poets to celebrate your Roman constancy, in particular oblige the tongue and pen of your devout honourer, —

sp.speaker: Orpiano.
sp.p: He does not mean this building for a college, I hope?

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: That were an ill foundation, there are more scholars then can live one by another already; 'tis pity we should have more plenty of learned beggars.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: 'Tis past all my conjecture, why he built it.

lg.l: Signior Perenotto, captain oth' guard
Is of counsel only with the Duke in't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Signior Orpiano, and Fulvio.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: My spark? Whither in such haste? Let us change air a little ▪

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You are travailing to your mistress ▪

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Madam Donella is newly returned to court.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: With the Princess?

lg.l: She was but late retired into the country:
What's the matter?
Your lordships I hope have heard, the Duke sent
post for them, as they say, there is something in't.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Does not your lordship know?

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Your lordship's wisdom and mine is much about a scantling then, yet for ought I hear, there be others of the court as ignorant as we — your honours pardon I beseech you, I must in all haste to the Princess's lodging.

lg.l: Farewell signior.
Your amorous lock has a hair out of order.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Umh? what an oversight was this of my barber, I must return now and have it corrected, dear sign.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Here's a courtier that will not miss a hair of his compliment, when he is to appear before his mistress: every morning does this fellow put himself upon the rack, with putting on's apparel, and manfully endures his tailor, when he screws and wrists his body into the fashion of his doublet — but that the court cannot subsist without a fool, I should marvel what this fellow does to follow it.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: There are more have much about his parcel of brains, the benefit of youth and good clothes procured their places, and ignorance and impudence have since maintained 'em.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Two great helps as the world goes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Clear the presence, the Duke is entering.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: I ever was obedient —

lg.l: 'Tis for thy honour, which I know ▪
Is to thyself a precious sound — that building
I late erected, then shall be thy palace.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Or my prison sir, if I do rightly understand.

lg.l: That name
Is too unworthy of it, my Eugenia,
Nor will it seem restraint to my loved daughter,
since free to all delights, thy mind shall be
It's own commander, every day shall strive
To bring thee in fresh rarities, time shall be.
Delighted with thy pleasures, and stay with thee.
Indeed I shall think time has lost his wings
When I am thus caged up.
Thou shalt give
To him feathers when thou pleasest. Mantua
Shall pour her raptures on thee — why have I
A crown, but to command what thou canst wish for,
My dear Eugenia.
A deer it seems,
For as you had suspicion of my wildness,
You'll measure out my walk.
I am thy father,
Who by example of the wisest Kings,
But build a place to lay my treasure in,
Safe from the robber, where I'll place a guard —

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Do you suspect I shall break prison?

lg.l: To keep off violence, and soliciting
Which may disturb thy pleasures, until we
Shall find out one to match thy birth and virtues,
My dukedom is too poor that way, maintain
Thy father's soul: thou hast no blood to mix
With any beneath prince — forget as I shall
Thy love was ever falling from thy greatness,
Into the arms of one carries but style of honour.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Sir, I am your daughter.

lg.l: Thou'st deserved my blessing, and thy obedience
In this, new crowns thy father: I see I need not
Urge what I am to move thee, and lay force,
Thy understanding does appear convinced,
And loving duty teaches thee to more,
Than the command — Perenotto —
What narrow ground I tread? I know he is
Too passionate to be denied his will,
And yet to yield will make me miserable;
'Tis my misfortune to be born so great.
Each common man and woman can enjoy
The air, when the condition of a Princess
Makes me a prisoner. But I must obey
In hope it will not last — I have a soul
Is full of grateful duty, nor will suffer me
Further dispute your precept: you have power
To steer me as you please.
All the graces
Speak in my girl — each syllable doth carry
A volume of thy goodness: all my cares
So well rewarded do convert to sweetness
I thank thy filial piety: know my girl
That place wherein I look so rich a jewel,
I do pronounce again, shall be thy paradise:
Thy paradise my Eugenia, saving that
In this man only finds no being — other
Delights shall stream themselves into thy bosom,
And those that pass, shall flow again t'invite
Thy sense to tasting — Perenotto.

sp.speaker: Peren.
sp.p: Your grace's pleasure?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Admit those ladies that attend —

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: The Duke shows much indulgence.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Observe the issue.

lg.l: We will not limit thy companions,
Elect what Mantuan beauties thou canst best
Delight in, they shall serve thee: or if some
Of your own train, whom we have thought most proper
To be your personal guard, affect you, theyEnter Donella Katherina, Mardona and Fidelia.
Attend our pleasures: see, they are ignorant
Yet of our purpose, if to any, thy
Affection be not free, thy breath discharge them,
And point thy own attendants.
I shall be pleased with your appointment,
Ladies, I know you love me.
Doth your grace hold suspicion, any of us
Serve you not with our heart?
I do not doubt,
or if I did, you now approach a trial,
For my sake can you be content to be
All prisoners.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: Prisoners?

lg.l: Yes, shut up close prisoners, and be barred
The conversation, nay the sight of men.
Marry heaven defend, wherein have we offended
That we must lose the sweet society
Of men.

sp.speaker: Mard.
sp.p: How have we forfeited our freedom?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No man argue — 'tis our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Alas madam, I am new contracted to a handsome signior.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: I have but newly entertained a servant, that gave me these gloves, they smell of him still, a sweet courtier.

lg.l: Not one man among so many ladies?
Not a gentleman-usher? Nor a page?
How shall we do madam?
I beseech your grace let me be exempted,
If I have committed an offence, deserves your anger,
Let one of your lords cut off my head rather, sign. Dondolo.
Shall we express,
So cold a duty to her highness? Fie ladies.
You shall but suffer with me: I partake
As much severity, as any of you shall.
I will expect your duties lords in silence,
Orpiano, you shall to Ferrara, with
Our daughter's picture, your commissions sealed —
Now fair ladies,
I hope you're fixed to wait upon Eugenia.
If your restraint be a burden, it shall be
In her power to enlarge you, and elect
New friends into your places.
'Tis our duties
To obey your grace and her.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Perenotto — are all things prepared?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: They are my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: For once then let us usher you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Whether do we go?

sp.speaker: Peren.
sp.p: I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Done.
sp.p: Whither?

lg.l: To take physic madam.
The Duke has prepared to stay all looseness in your bodies
You must be all fast: stone walls and mortar will bind.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Come follow with a courage.

sp.speaker: Donel.
sp.p: I hope we shall be allowed our little dogs and monkeys.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Sweet madam.
sp.stage: Exit omn. man. Fulu. Orp. dond. grutti.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Madam Katherina, they are gone signior.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Would I had known this afore?

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: The Duke will be censured for this act.

lg.l: 'Tis very strange, good lady,
I read a forced obedience in her eye,
Which hardly held up rain.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Save you dear sign. which way went the ladies?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: News, signior news.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I beseech you I may partake.

lg.l: Have you forgotten there was suspicion
She affected signior Philenzo the Cardinal's nephew?

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Alas poor gentleman, he suffers for't.

lg.l: By this restraint he would make her sure, his jealousy
Is not yet over — signior Morello, is your lock rectified,
You have missed your lady but a hair's breadth.
Nay, but my lords and gentlemen, where are the
Ladies gone indeed?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: We ha' told you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What, committed to new prison:

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Very true, signior.

lg.l: Our dancing days are done, shut up close, not
A man must enter.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Would I were a mouse then — why, but is the Duke mad ▪

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Take heed what you say signior: though we be no informers, yet walls have ears.

lg.l: Ears? Would I had left mine behind me, here's
News indeed!

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: And y ▪ and come a little sooner, you might ha' taken your leave, but 'twas your barber's fault.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Would he had left me ith' suds an hour ago! What shall we do gentlemen, 'tis a hard case, when a man that has an intention to marry and live honest —
How now, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Any thing, nothing: yet a man, yet no man for I want.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What? Thou'rt no capon I hope.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Money sir, will you spare any from your precious sins.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Thou'rt very free.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Yet sir I am in debt.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: What dost owe?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Nobody harm.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Whence cam'st —

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I dropped from the moon.

lg.l: So methinks , thou talkest very madly —
Thou'st much humour in thee.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Ha ye any thing to do that ye account impossible gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Why, wilt thou do't?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: And you'll pay for't. Let me have money enough and I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Yes I will hold.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'll lay with thee, what wilt hold —

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Why paradoxes.

sp.speaker: Grut. Dond.
sp.p: Paradoxes!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I hold you a paradox.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Let's hear some.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: There are no beasts but cuckolds and flatterers; no cold weather but i'th dog-days; no physic to a whore, no fool to an alderman, no scholar to a justice of peace, nor no soldier to a belt and buff jerkin.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: A smart fellow.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The Duke.

lg.l: So my fears are over, in her restraint I bury all my
Jealousies: — how now? What fellows this?

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Such an humorist as I never before conversed withal: it seems he makes himself free of all places.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What would he have?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Thy pardon mighty man, if it be no treason to pray for thee, save thee, wilt employ me? 'tis vacation, and I want work, ask me not what I can do, let me have money enough, and I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You have your senses?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Five, the small birds dare not peep for him, I take it: I can see greatness big with an impostume, yet towering in the air like a falcon: I can hear a man swear I am thy eternal slave, and will serve thee: when if opportunity were offered, for price of a plush cloak, he will be the first shall strip thee to the very soul: I can taste wine that another man pays for, and relish any thing that comes of free cost: I can smell a knave through a bar'd gown, a politician, through a surplice; a fool, through a scarlet outside: I can touch a wench better than a lute, and tell money with a secretary, to show I ha' lost my feeling: tush, all's nothing, I have a humour to do some thing to be talked on, nothing can come amiss to me, let me have money enough, and my life to a cheese pairing, I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You'll except somewhat.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Not to do o'er the seven wonders of the world, and demolish 'em when I ha' done, let me have money enough, what star so high, but I will measure by this Jacob's staff: divine money, the soul of all things sublunary, what lawyer's tongue will not be tipped with silver, and will not money with a judge make it a plain case, does not gouty greatness find ease with aurum palpabile, and he's a sleight physician cannot give a golden glister at a dead lift: — money, I adore thee, it comes near the nature of a spirit, and is so subtle it can creep in at a cranny, be present at the most inward counsels, and betray 'em: money, it opens locks, draws curtains, buys wit, sells honesty, keeps courts, sights quarrels, pulls down churches, and builds almshouses.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A wild fellow.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Will your grace have him punished for this insolence?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No, his humour is good mirth to us; whence art?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I am of no country.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I was born upon the sea.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: In a tempest I was told —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A blustering fellow.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thy name.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Rolliardo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And how long hast thou been mad thus?

lg.l: Your highness may be merry-and if you have no
Employment for me, I am gone.
Stay we command you, and bethink again,
What to except in your bold undertaking.
I except nothing, nothing Duke, it were no glory
Not to be general, active in all, let me have money
Enough and I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Will your grace set him a-work?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Name the action.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What say you to a lady?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I will fall upon her, as Jupiter on Danae, let me have a shower of gold, Acrisius brazen tower shall melt again, were there an army about it, I would compass her in a month or die for't.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Ha? — a lady without guard would try your wit, and money to get her love.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: A toy, a toy.

lg.l: Through a credulity, you may too much
Traduce the sex, and merit such a justice
No money will buy off: — admit some branches
Grow not so straight and beautiful, as nature
Intended them, will you disgrace the stem
Or for some woman's levity, accuse
That fair creation? Money buy their love
Promise a salary of that sacred flame
Themselves cannot direct, as guided by
Divine intelligence.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
Your highness' pardon; if you prohibit I must not undertake, but let me have freedom, and money enough (For that's the circle I walk in) and if I do not conjure up a spirit hot enough to inflame a frozen Lucrece bosom: make mummy of my flesh, and sell me to the apothecaries: try me with some master piece; a woman's love is as easy as to eat dinner without saying grace, getting of children, or going to bed drunk: let me have
money enough, and tax me to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Fulu. Orp.
sp.p: He's constant.

lg.l: Admit there be a lady, whom a prince
Might court for her affection; of a beauty,
Great as her virtue, add unto them birth,
Equal to both, and all three but in her
Not to be matched — suppose this miracle
(Too precious for man's eye) were shut up, where
A guard more watch ull then the dragons; did
Forbid access to mankind: — men picked out
Between whose souls and money were antipathy
Beyond that which we know; and you as soon
Might bribe to be a saint: — what would you do
With your enough of money, were your life
Engaged to win her love?
The sky may fall, and aldermen cry larks
About the city.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The fellow's impudent: sirrah, thou hast landed thyself upon a rock, you shall have sense of what you would contemn, a life: put on a most fortified resolution, you shall need it; we have a daughter thus locked up —

sp.speaker: Fulv,
sp.p: What does the Duke mean?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A virgin.

sp.speaker: Orp.
sp.p: He is in passion.

lg.l: Shalt not engage thee on a work so much
Impossible as procurement of her love,
Make it appear with all the art thou canst
Get but access to her; a month we limit
But take heed boaster, if you fail; your life
Shall only satisfy our charge, and teach
All other mountibanks to be at distance,
With such bold undertakings: you shall expect
A severe justice:
By this, I shall try the fidelity of those are trusted.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: 'Tis a match, I shall have money enough?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You shall. What d'ye call enough, yet it shall be under 20. thousand crowns: I will not leave the pawn here, for twice so much.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I will not be particular and agree oth' sum, you look I should die if I perform not, and I'll look to be merry and want nothing while I live, I'll not take the advantage on you, because I hope to receive credit by it: if I use now and then a round sum set me up oth' ticket for't, but who shall pass his word if I do this feat, you'll let me keep my head a my shoulders.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Our royal word secure thee.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: 'Tis enough.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: What security can your grace expect for his forthcoming, if he fail.

lg.l: We ha' studied that,
'Tis but the loss of some superfluous crowns,
Let the end carry what success fate please,
All the expense will not be lost, to try
The faith of those we shall employ in this;
Our city's strong, the river that environs
On three parts, shall be carefully attended,
A wall makes safe the fourth, which shall be guarded
Our vigils shall be so exact, he shall
Deserve his liberty, if he escape us,
We are constant sir.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Would he might pay for his curiosity.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I'll wait upon your highness for some earnest: I have a month good, let me have fair play and my bargain money enough, if I do come short, let my head be too heavy for my shoulders; if I do more than is expected, you'll believe it possible hereafter: when a man has money enough he may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Maintain your humour still — attend us.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Here's a mad fellow, does he mean to get into the ladies?

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: It seems so.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Or I would not be in his taking when the moon changes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Our best course then is to observe and humour him, he may have a trick more than we know; he seems to be a good fellow, let's be drunk together, and get him to confess it — ha?

sp.speaker: Don. Grut.
sp.p: A match.

lg.l: Like errand knights our valiant wits must wrestle
To free our ladies from the enchanted castle.

div.head: Scaena. i.

lg.l: D'ye think this hair
And habit will sufficiently disguise you,
From your inquiring creditors?
No question,
Have you dispersed my bills about the city,
Does every public place carry the scroll,
As I commanded?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I have been careful.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: What do they say abroad, do they not wonder?

lg.l: They are strucken dumb at reading, he that has
The use of tongue, employs it to express
His admiration of your art, your deep,
Invisible art.
There's hope than we shall prosper,
In this believing age, Italy is full
Of juggling mountibanks, that show tricks with oils,
And powders, here an empiric dares boast
Himself a paracelsian, and daub
Each post with printed follies, when he went
A'th ticket with some midwife, or old woman
For his whole stock of physic, here a fellow
Only has skill to make a handsome periwig,
Or to sow teeth i'th gums of some state madam,
Which she coughs out again, when so much phlegm
As would not strangle a poor flea, provokes her,
Proclaims himself a rectifier of nature,
And is believed so, getteth more by keeping
mouths in their quarterly reparations,
Then knowing men for all their art, and pains
I'th cure of the whole body — shall we doubt
To be made rich, rich Carlo, by our art
Whereof I am the first and bold professor
In Italy, we shall grow fat and purchase,
Dost not think so?
To go invisible
Who will not learn at any rate.
True Carlo.
There may be in the throng of our admirers,
Some will presume't above the power of art
To make men walk and talk invisible.
But we can clear the mystery, and make
Mantua in the proof acknowledge it
A matter feasible — here's some customerEnter Rolliardo.
Ha? 'tis the humorist, the undertaker,
The bird I spread my art for, he has money
Enough, and's apt to prove a fortune to me.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: So the covenants are sealed, I am like a famous cathedral with two ring of bells, a sweet chime a both sides, now 'tis noised I ha' money enough, how many gallants of all sorts and sexes court me, here's a gentleman ready to run himself in the kennel, for haste to give me the wall, this cavalier will kiss my hand, while th'other signior crinkles ith' hams, as he were studying new postures against his turn comes to salute me. As I walk, every window is glazed with eyes, as some triumph were in the street; this madonna invites me to a banquet for my discourse, tother bona roba sends me a spark, a third a ruby, a fourth an emerald, and all but in hope to put their jewels to usury, that they may return again with precious interest — thus far it goes well, very well, what's next -

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Save you signior.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: One appointed by fate to do you service sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
But I gave fate no commission to take you up for
me, I ha' more followers than the Duke already, prithee have me commended to the lady destinies, and tell 'em I am provided.

lg.l: Mistake me not, he speaks to you, has power
To make you happy.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Prithee make thyself happy with a warm suit first, thy house is but poorly thatched, and thou beest so good at making happy, why hast no better clothes.

lg.l: 'Tis no felicity, or admit: the sun
Dispenceth a rich warmth about the world
Yet hath no heat itself.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Philosophy.

lg.l: To omit circumstance, I know what you
Have undertaken to the general
Amazement: upon penalty of death,
You must procure access to the fair Princess,
'Tis in my art to help — to perfect what
The Duke holds so impossible.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How canst thou assist me.

lg.l: Although my outside promise not, my brain
Is better furnished, I ha' gained by study
A secret, will advance the work you labour with,
I'll teach you sir to go invisible —

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How? t'hast no cloven foot, I sent brimstone, and thou beest a devil tell me.

lg.l: I trifle not, I am a man, whose fame
Shall outlive time, in teaching you this mystery
For which I must expect reward — you are,
(Loud noise proclaims it) able, and can pay me
Out of the Duke's exchequer, being yourself
His walking treasury.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: You'll teach me to go invisible you say.

lg.l: I can, and with your safety, for I deal not
With magic, to betray you to a faith
Black and satanical, I abhor the devil.

sp.speaker: R●ll.
sp.p: Very like so.

lg.l: Which some have conjured into a ring,
To effect the wonder, I admit of no
Suffumigation, incense offered to
infernal spirits, but by art, whose rules
Are lawful and demonstrative —

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: You think I admire you all this while — hark, when did you eat? or do you hope again, that you are put to this pitiful and desperate exigent. I see you my would be invisible, fine knave.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: D'ye mock me, sir?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I'll tell you a better project, wherein no courtier has prefooled you. Stick your skin with feathers, and draw the rabble of the city for pence a piece to see a monstrous bird brought from Peru, baboons have passed for men already, been taken for usurers, i'their furred gowns and nightcaps, keep a fool in pay, to tell the multitude of a gentle faith, that you were caught in a wilderness, and thou mayst be taken for some far country owlet.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Do you despise my art?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Art? but such another word, and I shall mar the whole expectation of your invisible traffic, in, to your nest; and leave me, distinguish men before you practise on 'em, 'tis wholesome caution.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I leave you to the misery of your unbelief, when you hear of me hereafter, you will curse your fortune to have thus neglected me, fare you well, sir.

div.stage: Enter Perenotto, with 3. or 4. of the guard.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: This is Perenotto captain of the guard.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Not yet attempted you?
We have not seen him my lord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: He's here.
Is that he that has gold enough? would I had some of his yellow hammers.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: D'ye hear, you are one of the list.
A poor Halbert man sir.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Poor? hold thee, there's gold for thee: — thou wilt be honest now?
O yes sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Not a penny, and thou hadst not been a fool, thou wouldst ha' been a knave, and so thou mightst have got by me, yet by those scurvy legs there's some hope thou'lt be converted at all adventures take it.
I will be what you please sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Tell me what condition is that sign. of? is he rich?
He loves money.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Come? Shalt be my pensioner — here's more gold for

D'ye make question of that sir? he bought his office, and therefore may sell his conscience, he has sold 200. on's twice over, he was brought up at court, and knows what belongs to his place, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Good.
Am I not a knave now sir?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I like thee.
To your cost: — I hope you won't tell him what I say: but if you do, and he chance to turn me out of my office, your gold is restorative.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To your stations, and be circumspect.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Noble sir, you are the only man I have ambition to honour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I should be proud to merit such a phrase.

lg.l: 'Tis in your power to oblige my soul — we're private,
I am jealous of the wind lest it convey
Our noise too far: this morn I had some traffic
With a jeweller, and if my judgement err not,
Has richly furnished me.
What says your lordship to this diamond?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis a glorious one.

lg.l: Does it not sparkle most divinely signior,
A row of these stuck in a lady's forehead,
Would make a Persian stagger in his faith,
And give more adoration to this light
Then to the sun beam: I ha' fellows to 'em
A nest of bright ones.
This box is studded like a frosty night with stars
You have out bid their value, make me a gainer
In changing them for your commends.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I'm serious.

lg.l: I never shall deserve this bounty, if
You'd point me out some service to begin my gratitude —
You have a noble soul
I'll teach you how to merit more.

sp.speaker: Peren.
sp.p: I am covetous of such a knowledge.

lg.l: Make but my path a smooth one to the Princess,
I am brief, you know my undertaking.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: So I should be a traitor.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: It comes not near the question of a life: do't I'll enable you, to buy another dukedom, state, and title.

lg.l: Although 'twere necessary in the affairs
Of such high consequence to deliberate,
Yet for this once, I'll be as brief as you,
I won't do't.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How?

lg.l: No indeed signior, you shall pardon me
At this time, and I'll keep your jewels too
For they are gifts: hereafter you will know me
So fare you well sir.
Was I not told this officer was corrupt?
I want faith to believe the miracle.
Sure he does but jest with me, ha?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The guard will accept no money.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What an ago do we live in, when officers will take no bribes.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Not the golden one.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Here's Rolliardo.

sp.speaker: Roll
sp.p: I'm quite lost.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: 'Tis he.

lg.l: Yet he keeps my jewels, there may be some hope
I'll to him again, 'tis but his modesty
At first not to see me easy, he must be courted
Statesmen like virgins first, should give denial,
Experience and opportunity make the trial.
Save you gallants.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And you go thereto: save yourself, you are in a worse pickle than we are.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: And how is't we signior?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Do you thrive in your hopes?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I do not despair gentlemen, you see I do not wear my hat in my eyes, crucify my arms, or entreat your lordship's brain to melt in a petition for me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
I did but jest, I know you have a way to the
wood in your pericranium, what is't we are honest simple minded lords.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Nay nay, impart.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: We tell no tales.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Wooed we were whipped and we do.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Why shall I tell you — you are three.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Very secret —

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: A miserable leash of court mimics.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mimics? what's that.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: You perfumed goats.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: O is that it, I never heard what a mimic was before.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: D'ye think I am so wretched in a point that concerns my life and honour, to trust my ways and purposes to you that have no souls.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No souls.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Peace how comes he to know that?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Why hast thou none?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: 'Twas more than ever I could see in myself yet.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Things that have forfeited their creation, and had not your tailors took compassion on you, you had died to all men's thoughts, who long since would ha' forgotten that ever there were such things in nature.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Shall we suffer this?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Yes, and make legs, in token of your thankfulness, if I were at leisure, I would make you show tricks now.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Do I look like a johnanapes?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: But I wonot.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: It were not your best course.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Alas sir I should but shame myself, and be laughed at afore all this company.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
When you see me next avoid me, as you would do your poor kindred when they come to court.
Get you home, say your prayers, and wonder that you come off without beating, for 'tis one of my miracles.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Had we not better a gone to tavern, as I plotted at first, he could not ha' been more valiant in his drink.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: I'm glad he's gone.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I know not what to make on him.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Make on him quotha, he made little reckoning of us, but and he had not gone as he did, I should ha' made

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Urine in my breeches — he squeezed me, I think I was ready to melt'o, both sides.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: But hark you signior, we forget the ladies still

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Well remembered.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Let's consult to purpose about that — shall we?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: No, every one think what he can by himself, my thoughts shall be private, and not free at this time; every one scratch his own head.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And he that gets the first hint, communicate —

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Let me see — umh.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What if I did — nothing, my brains are dull.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Ten to one, but if I did — let it alone, a pox on't, I were best drink some sack, they say it helps invention.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: O rare.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Rub rub, out with it.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: No, 'tis gone back again, I drunk buttered sack this morning and it slipped back when 'twas almost at my tongue's end — but it was a delicate project, whatsoever it was.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Recover it with thy finger.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Follow it Morello.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now, now, now, let me alone — make no noise, 'tis coming again, I have't, I have't —

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hold it fast now.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Lose it not, thou art great with wit, let us deliver thee, what, is't?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Some wiser than some.
sp.stage: They follow him up and down for discovery.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wilt not tell us?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Didst not promise.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: No haste — as occasion serves — it cost more than so yet you may know't.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Hereafter, but not now — away, do not tempt me I will eat the sweat of my own brain, oh rare! never was such a strain of wit invented. — d'ye hear, gentlemen; if you will command me any service to the ladies, I do purpose to visit 'em — with quirk — heigh.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Marry do I.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Nay More-clack.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Gentlemen, as I told you, if you have any thing to the ladies, before I go I am the messenger, — there is a crotchet and so forth — a carwhichet is found out - your ears — I will do such a stratagem as never the like was heard of in the world. — o rare. —

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He's mad.

lg.l: So am I, that he is so reserved
What shall's do.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Save you signiors, pray whereabouts is the sign of the invisible man.

sp.speaker: D. G.
sp.p: The invisible man.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Cry ye mercy now I see it.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: See't he does more than we can, the gentleman's mistaken, here's no such sign, yet he went in there.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He has better eyes than we to distinguish it.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: This, it his is it.

sp.speaker: Don
sp.p: What is it pray?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: In courtesy we ask:

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Then by the sign this is the house, whether I am going to inquire for a gentleman that teaches men to walk invisible.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: That would be seen, this is news.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: News, either you have slept long, or you are gentlemen of very small intelligence, examine the next paper you see advanced, and inform yourselves, farewell gallants.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He's entered there to.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Teach men to walk invisible, a very fine trade.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Would 'twere true, we should desire no other device to get into the ladies.

div.stage: Enter Bonamico and servant in other disguises.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible — see, see, more gentlemen, prithee let's to him, this will be a trick worth our learning.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Stay, we are not acquainted, let's knock first.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Your pleasure's gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Pray sir, what signs is this?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The invisible man sir.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Man, I see no man.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Here's nothing but a cloud.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Right sir, and he's behind it, the man's invisible.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Pretty faith, it may be the man i'the moon for ought we know.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Would ye any thing with my master.

sp.speaker: Grut
sp.p: He does teach to walk invisible they say.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: He is the only professor of the miraculous invisible art.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: May we change a little discourse with him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: There are some gentlemen with him — but I'll tell him, I am prevented, he's coming forth himself.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Signior Altomaro I take it.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: 'Tis my name sir, a poor artist, not warm in these parts of Italy.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And you were not too busy sir —

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Please you walk in, I am now alone, your persons will grace my poor habitation.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: We saw 4. or 5. enter but now.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I ha dispatch 'em they are fresh departed.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Which way.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Here's not a man, are they not sunk, came they out here?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Upon my credit sir no other way.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Then they went invisible.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Right sir, they came hither to that purpose, their designs required haste.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: This man can do't I see already.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sir if you can assure us this invisible walking, for we are not so ignorant as we seem, we ha' seen the play of the invisible knight, and —

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: That of the ring too, ha ye not.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p:
The one was magic, and tother an imposture, what I do is by art fair and natural, are you in debt and fear arresting, you shall save your money in protections, come up to the face of a sergeant, nay walk by a shoal of these mankind horseleeches, and be mace proof. If you have a mind to rail at 'em, or kick some a their loose flesh out, they sha'not say blacks your eye, nor with all their lynx''s eyes discover you: would you see when the mercers abroad, how his man plays the merchant at home with his mistress silkworm, and deals underhand for commodity — would yourself talk with a lady in secret, sit down, play with her, ravish a diamond from her finger, and bind her soft wrist with a bracelet, kiss her abroad, at home, before her servants, in the presence
of her jealous husband, nay truss her up, when the tame lord is a-bed with her, and to his eyes be undiscovered as the wind signior — do you suspect your mistress plays double? would you hear how she entertains the tother's love, and know what she does i'the closet with the smooth page — would you be present at secret counsels, betray letters, see how such a lord paints his thighs, this perfume his breath, tother marshal his fine French teeth, see this statesman's eyes put out with a bribe, how that officer cozens the Duke, and his secretary abuses 'em both, this lawyer takes fees a both sides; while the judge examines the fertility, and price of the manor, before the witnesses and then decrees who shall have the land? would you see justice employ her scales to weigh light gold, that comes in for fees or corruption, and flourish with her sword like a fencer to make more room for causes i'the court.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: All this and more may be done, if we can but go invisible, but how can you assure us of that. I would fain see any man go invisible once.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: See him sir?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Video pro intelligo I mean sir.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Nay sir you need not distinguish, for it is possible to see a man invisible observe me, you see me now perfectly, in every part, if I should walk before you without a body.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: My head only visible and hanging in the air like a comet.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: That were a strange sight?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Sometimes nothing shall be seen but my arm, another while one of my legs, hopping without a body.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: This is admirable.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: When I please I will have nothing conspicuous, but my hand, nay, perhaps my little finger.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Do not you conjure then?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Come you will cast a mist before our eyes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: 'Tis a mystery indeed but a safe one signiors.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p:
Why look you sir, if you will be pleased that
we may see you first walk invisible, we shall not only credit your art, but at any rate be ambitious to be your disciples.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Why gentlemen, you speak but justice, you shall have experiment. I will be invisible first, but as to other in this kind, I will not demonstrate without half in hand, let me have 50. Crowns apiece, I'll point you a day when I will be invisible ▪

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Can you not do it presently.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I can be invisible in a twinkling, but what assurance can you have, that I am here at the same instant, when you see no part of me, I may deceive you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He says true.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I do purpose therefore to give you reality and proof, for I will walk invisible, all but — my hand.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Your hand?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Only my hand, you shall touch it, see every line in't, and the rest of my body be to you invisible, this will require a little time for preparation, and when with the consent of your eyes and understandings, I keep my promise in this point, you will think your moneys well expended to be taught the mystery.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: This is very fair.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: The crown shall be ready sir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Expect 'em within this hour.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: At your own pleasures, ha Rolliardo? I must not be seen gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Farewell incomparable signior — what luck had we to light upon this artist, he sha'not publish it, we'll buy the whole secret at any value, and then get him remove into some other province, who's this.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
Am not I mad, sure I am, though I do not know it, and all the world is but a bedlam, a house of correction to whip us into our senses, I ha' known the time when jewels and gold had some virtue in 'em, the generation of men now are not subject to corruption; Democritus the
world's refined.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: 'Tis Rolliardo, he looks melancholy, let's have a fling at him, give you joy of the great lady sir, which is the next way to the moon pray?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Bolt upright Muskat, and if you make haste you may be one of her calves, next time she appears, you shall see her because to you, with a pair of horns, just a'the size of those are preparing for your forehead, my precious animal.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, the fellows mad.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Can you tell sir, what became of all the swallows, cuckoos, and small birds, we had here last summer?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Marry sir they went to sea, to aid the cranes, and there have been mustering ever since, but for want of a woodcock they ha' left behind 'em, they dare not venture upon the pigmies, you may do well to overtake the buzzard and relieve the army sir.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I shall be grinned to death as I walk the streets, 'tis no policy to be dull and modest — but let me see, which way to compass my work, and put myself out of the common laughter the very children will jeer me shortly I think, and point me out with stones, the precious undertaker. I might have had more wit than to run myself into this calamity whom have we next.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke, ambassador, Fulvio, Dondolo, grutti attendants, courtiers.
sp.p: The Duke? what stranger's that? I must not seem dejected.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: Is this he your highness discoursed of?

lg.l: This is the piece made up of all performance
The man of any thing without exception,
Give him but gold, Kings daughters and their heirs
Though locked in towers of brass, are not safe from him.
Nay though I play the chemist with my trust
And from a million of sure confidences
I draw the spirit of honesty into a few,
He can corrupt 'em.
You are my prince great sir, and you have spoke
Not much unlike a brave one.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He'll jeer the Duke too

lg.l: If my head
Come to be paid to you, before sunset
That day when it is forfeit, I ha' cleared with you,
And shall depart out of your royal debt
There's all you can demand, a good sharp sword
Will make an even reckoning.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: He seems confident.

sp.speaker: Courtier 1.
sp.p: With your grace's leave, let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Now a fierce dog.
What came into thy mind, thou daring madman, fool is a word of favour to thee.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: So sir.
To undertake such an impossible task.

lg.l: Mushroom — I'll cast away a few words on thee
Had I another life, I'd undertake yet
Though I below in all opinion,
To venture it, with the riches I have spread
To corrupt others, to make thee my parasite,
I would engage my life to wear no steps
To thy white daughter, thou and thy grave matron
Most humbly should present her, when I was pleased too
For fear I should refuse the sport you brought me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I never knew man bear his scorn so high, too him some other.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Not I sir, you shall excuse me, 'twas the last thing I did.

lg.l: In the position general, 'I'll not touch him
For money may be said to purchase all things
But to aspire to my good sovereign's daughter
Of blessed memory.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: She's not dead I hope.

lg.l: There gold and trash was impudently inferred,
And 'twas a task too insolent, in that point
You'd willingly give a pound of your proud flesh,
To be released.
I heard a pound of flesh, a Jews demand once
'Twas gravely now remembered of your lordship — released?
Fortune, and courtesy of opinion
Gives many men nobility of birth,
That never durst do nobly, nor attempt
Any design, but fell below their honours.
Cased up in chambers, scarcely air themselves
But at a horse-race, or i'th park with puppets,
That for which I'm your laughter, I speak to
You flattering tribe of courtiers, to you glowworms
Is my chief glory, that perhaps being sprung
From humble parentage, dare yet attempt
A deed so far above me, that sets all
Your wisdoms in combustion, you may think
I've made a sorry bargain for my life,
Let scorners know in aiming at her only
My memory after death, receives more honour
Than all your marble pinnacles can raise you,
Or alabaster figures, whiter far
Then ere your souls were, and that hour I die
If you dare look upon me, without fainting
(Which I much fear) you shall see death so scorned,
I mean for any terror, you shall think him
My slave to take my upper garment off.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I told your highness — how you should find him.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: A brave resolution.

lg.l: Be this the prologue to the mirth, my lord
Attends to entertain you; set on, we'll leave him. Ha, ha, ha.
Sir, I observed you noble, and not apt
To throw derision on me with the rest,
Which does encourage me, to ask you a question.

sp.speaker: Fulu.
sp.p: Name it sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Pray what stranger's that walked with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: 'Tis an ambassador from Florence sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: An ambassador, his design I pray?

lg.l: To treat of marriage betwixt our Princess
And the great Duke's son, desired much by our master
Who has some hope, t' will be effected too.
Has brought rich presents to her.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: You have it freely.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: You've honoured me, married to Tuscany? so, if my ambition had been fortunate, I might have been his taster, but my stars want influence, they are too dull, and weary of my fate, Rolliardo then must forfeit, why that's the worst on't, I will make a glorious blaze in death, and while I live, make the Duke's treasure pay for't, nor shall he accuse me, I exhaust him poorly, I'll study out some noble way to build me a remembrance. ha. — a church or college? Tedious, my glass has but few sands, I must do some thing I may live to finish: I have't, I will send to all the prisons ith' city, and pay the poor men's debts for 'em: the world wants such a precedent: I ha' money enough since I fail in my other ends, I will do some good deeds before I die, so shall I be more sure of prayers, then if I built a church, for they are not certain to continue their foundation, fate I despise thee, I sink under no cheap and common action, but sell my life too fame, in catching my death by so brave an aspiring.

lg.l: If I obtain a monument, be this all
Write on my grave. This man climbed high to fall.

div.head: Scaena i.

sp.p: Come gentlemen, we must watch still, that none run away with the Princess.
He must have an excellent stomach, that can break these stone walls to come to her.
Beside this movable wall of flesh which we carry.
One makes towards us, — 'tis a lady.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: So, now am I as valiant as Hercules, when he turned spinster, great Jupiter, the patron of scapes, assist my petticoat, and at my return, I will sacrifice my linen-breeches to thee, — here be the men, the men of mettle, now Venus I beseech thee, and they be men they will let a lady enter without many questions.
Save you sweet lady, your affairs this way?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I go but in to the Princess.
From whom?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: From the Duke's grace.
What may be your ladyship's name?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I never thought to give myself a name — my name is madam — umh. My name is something an odd name, but — I do not stand upon't — my name's thorn.
Indeed madam thorn, if his grace have sent you to such a purpose, you must show something for our discharge.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Why hark you it was but forgotten, of the Duke to send his signet — but I ha' brought some of his highness' deputies wi'me, I hope that will satisfy.
sp.stage: As he takes out money discovers breeches.

sp.p: By this gold, breeches
No, they are but silk — here will be sport, I have a hint already.
Say you so? 'tis very well — but madam, we are many, and we would be loath to venture — deal ingeniously sweet lady, have you no more gold in your breeches?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not a doit, as I am virtuous and sinful.
Pass — but d'ye hear — and you should not be secret now.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman.
A gentleman? dost hear him? I'll put him to't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have left some crowns with your fellow.
Tush, that won't satisfy me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed, I ha' no more money.
You have commodity, hang this transitory gold — give me — what's this?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nothing but a wart a'my little finger.
A wart, let me see't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Tis a diamond, 'twas my mother's legacy — or else
Is it your will I should have it?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It was my mother's will I should wear it, her ghost will haunt me, and I should give it away.
You know the way back lady.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You will give me my gold again.
Not a doit, as I am virtuous and sinful, stand with him for a toy, and know you've no warrant from the Duke, 'tis in our power.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: D'ye hear sir, and it were a diamond of gold you should have it.
Lady, I kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You've kissed the ring of a my finger I'm sure.
Use your fortune, pass.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If I get to the ladies, somebody shall pay for this, that's my comfort.
Can you wrestle madam.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ah — wrestle sir, ladies do not use to wrestle.
They are thrown down with their good wills then, come you and I will have a bout, I must hug your little body.
Humour him, and you're passed danger.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Would you ha' me tear my clothes?
I'll persuade him.

To tell you true madam, this fellow is an abominable
lecher, there is no scaping him without a fall, a very satire, he leaps all comes near him, if your ladyship's modesty can dispense with a private favour — you understand; for our parts, we are satisfied otherwise, and our lips are sowed up, take him a 'Toside, and see how you can mollify him, he's a cock a the game, and will tread you and you were ten thorns.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mollify him, doth he use ladies so, he will mollify me.

And you were his sister, all's one to him, the devil is not more hot and robustious, where he finds opposition to the sport; therefore the Duke made choice of him, as suspecting some lord might come disguised a this fashion, to prevent dishonour to the Princess and ladies — use your own discretion.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What will become of me, if he be such a wencher he'll ravish me, and discover all, what a rascal was I to venture thus, I'll give thee my fan to persuade him — help, help.

lg.l: Nay then. He throws him down, and discovers his breeches.
Why how now? Breeches?

sp.p: This is a man.
Sure 'tis a woman.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: To tell you true gentlemen, I am neither a man nor a woman, I am an hermaphrodite.
How? an hermaphrodite? What would you do among the ladies then.
An hermaphrodite.
Let's search him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ah.
Stay let's be advised, if he be such a monster, our best way is to carry him to the Duke.
Agreed.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I shall be undone — d'ye hear noble friends 'tis but a folly to dissemble, I am no such thing, I am no hermaphrodite, I am a friend of yours.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Of ours.
Your name, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I did but jest all this while, the Duke himself put me upon't, to see whether I could cozen you, my name's Morello.
Signior Morello, 'tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: As I am virtuous, I am, I am no hermaphrodite, no matter for the gold or diamonds 'tis your own — I'll acquaint his grace how careful I found you, and if he do not reward you beside, I'll say he's the poorest Duke in Christendom: I'll tell him presently.
Noble signior we'll wait upon you to him.

sp.speaker: Mo,
sp.p: No, no, 'tis better for me to go alone.
Your pardon, you shall tell him how careful you found us we'll relate to him how cunningly you carried the business.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Nay d'ye hear gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: It must be so sir, come sweet effeminate signior.

lg.l: You've done me a noble office signior in this
Discovery, where now lives her banished lover?
My kinsman lives in Florence, but 2. days since
I received letters from him.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: In Florence too?

lg.l: Sir you may censure me,
But my affection to the injured lord,
And not without respect unto the honour,
Of your master too, hath been the cause of
My free language.
Trust me signior
We are all engaged to study you a recompense,
But Mantua was injust to banish him,
For being too much a servant.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Sir, when princes resolve to punish.

lg.l: Virtue shall be treason
'Twas tyranny, — why now is she thus caged?
I can conjecture nothing but his jealousy
Which will be ever active, by that love
We interchanged at Pisa, when we grew
Together in our studies — I conjure
Your nobleness to silence me.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: You will dishonour me by suspicion: — I am charmed.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: My honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: Signior Perenotto.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: My gentile sparks.

sp.speaker: Doctor Gr.
sp.p: Your servants.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: You are all courtship.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Is your lordship for this wonder?

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: What wonder my lord?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: These pair of gentlemen have discoursed me into admiration, there's one has undertaken to go invisible.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: Invisible?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This hour expected, and in this place.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: With a trick that he has.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Do you believe him, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: You shall see't.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: We were heretics in that point, but our understandings are convinced, he did demonstrate.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And because you shall know the truth of his art, he will be invisible all but his hand, what think you of that? the rarest fellow in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: Nothing visible but his hand.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: As sure as we have given him a 100. Crowns in hand.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: Why is not the Duke presented with this novelty.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He's travailing to the emperor first, only as he goes for our sake, he will show us a fegary of his art.
Here's Rolliardo, he's somewhat costive a tother side wants faith.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Save you nest of courtiers, smooth faces, rich clothes, and sublime compliments, make you amorous in sight of your ladies. Donzell deal Phebo, and Rosicleer are you there? what pestilent diseases have you got, that you wear so much musk and civet about you. O for a priest of Cupid to sacrifice you now, how your breeches would burn like incense, and your hair disguised in sweet powder, leave your bodies in a mist, while your bones were inwardly consuming with the fire of dame Venus' altar.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: The same humorist still.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I heard say, we shall have strange apparitions i'th air and yet invisible wonders, a hand must appear as fatal to some as that hung o'er the Capitol; for there is a suspicion some purses will be juggled empty, and as silent as the moon, no bright sol appearing, nor a piece of pale faced silver in your silken hemispheres.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He is an infidel.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Right Jehochanan, right, my precious Jew, we are all in fiddle that wonot believe the court catechism - my lord ambassador you are welcome from Florence, does the great Duke pick salads still, I mean continue his assize, return into his exchequer once in seven years the wealth of Tuscany. Vespasian was held covetous for ordaining vessels to receive the beneficial public urine, but 'tis heathenism among Christians not to hold dulcis odour lucri è re qualibut.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: He's mad.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Signior Perenotto, it has puzzled my understanding, how you can subsist at court without making use of the common sins, flattery, and corruption; take heed, you're a great man, and 'tis ominous to die in your bed, a sign your children are like to inherit but weak brains, thou mayst go to heaven, but thy heir had rather thou shouldst make a journey to Erebus, for the proverb's sake, happy is that son, whose father goes to the devil. — why when comes out my don invisible, may be, he's here already for we cannot see him, what says my squirrel? thou lookest dull and physical methinks , the crowns will return again invisibly, never fear it, and how does my grave gymnosophist whose ambition is to be registered an honest lord, though thou beest buried upon alms, carried to church with four torches, and have an inscription on thy marble worse than the ballad of the devil and the baker, and might be sung to as vild a tune too. — gentlemen, I'll invite you shortly to see my head cut off, and do only entreat, you would not laugh at me when I am dead, 'twill show but poorly in you, and I shall revenge it with my ghost walking.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Either he is very confident to achieve his design or late grown desperate, he talks so wildly.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p:
I wonder, signior Altomaro forgets us. Now, now, ye shall hear, this is his servant I know he is not
far off, where is thy master?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: He is invisible — this letter is directed to you.

body.head: The letter.
body.p: Gentlemen, that you may perceive I deal plainly with you, I am now invisible; all but my hand, and here it is, you may with ease read every line, as I promised upon the receipt of your crowns. — his hand.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I sir, 'tis his own hand I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He does not mean to serve us so, thou dost but jest, where is he invisible.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here I think, for I cannot see him, nor do I know when I shall, or where he will be visible again, upon diligent search I found this paper, but my master is not to be found.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Then he is invisible indeed.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: All but his hand. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: I do incline to believe, that we are cheated.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: With a trick that he has. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.p: You were heretics in that point, till he did demonstrate. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I cannot contain my merry spleen. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Come my lord, let's leave them now, to be their own derision.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Signior Morello, ha, ha, ha. How came he in a petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Carry me away quickly, they will laugh me out of my little wit.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: No, no, do not gentlemen, remember yourselves.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: We wonot then.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Morello? 'I'll wait upon him to the Duke myself.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What wise man in Italy would be in my coat now.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p:
I was costive, and an infidel, you are Christian coxcombs, and so, while I see what will become of the mirth, that is gone before, I leave your wise signiorships
to the mercy of your garters, which is a speedy way, after a little time, to make yourselves invisible indeed. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Signior Grutti we are gulled.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I always thought he would cheat us, what shall's do, to prevent more laughter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I am resolved — I shall get no more money by him, gentlemen be not head-hung, droop not, 'tis in this sconce, to revenge yourselves, and it may be, recover your crowns too.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My master —

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Is invisible, we know't too well.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What will you give me, if I discover him to your eyes again, nay give him to your possession. Give him money.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: This.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And this — o quickly.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Then first know, my master is not that man you took him for, no Altomaro he, but Bonamico the decayed artist, he that made properties, and grew poor for want of pictures, who for fear of his creditors left his dwelling, and in this quaint disguise, set up the trade of cozening such wise gentlemen as you are.

sp.speaker: Grut. Dond.
sp.p: Bonamico!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: O that we could reach him again.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Follow me close, and I will bring you within an hair's breadth of his false beard immediately.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: That will be excellent.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Nimbly good Mercury, nimbly.

div.stage: Enter Eugenia, Fidelia, Mardona, Donella, Catarina, Cassiava.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Madam you are too passive, if you be dejected what must we, whose hopes and blisses depend upon your fortune.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O liberty, liberty; are all the Roman spirits extinct? Never a Brutus in nature, to deliver poor ladies from this captivity.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p:
Since there is no probability of our enlargement, let's be merry, and despise our sufferings, laugh, tell tales,
sing, dance, any thing to cozen our melancholy.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: There are some thoughts that stick upon my memory, I would fain discharge.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Shall we try our lutes madam?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And voices if you please.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes you may try, they say music built the walls of Thebes, it were a greater miracle if you could charm these to fall, I shall never endure to live an anchorite thus, and it were not for the happiness that I do sometimes dream of a man, I should leap the battlement. Now would I give all my jewels for the sight of a pair of breeches, though there were nothing in 'em.
This but feeds our dulness, shall we dance madam and stir ourselves.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: I am for that music, we shall grow to the ground and we use no more activity.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: None a your dull measures, there's no sport but in your country fegaries, a nimble dance will heat, and and make us merry.

div.stage: They dance, which done, a bell rings.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Hark, the bell.

stage.p: Exit Donella, and enters again with a letter.

lg.l: Some news from the Duke.
A letter madam and these jewels.
Ha! whence — from Florence? Reads.
This is my father's practice, I'll peruse the paper.
I have an excellent hint ladies of a mirth,
Cannot but please the Princess.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: What is't?

lg.l: It will require every ones endeavour,
What if we play some pretty comic story,

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: A play?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Shall we?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: We? Do not distrust your own performance, I ha' known men ha' been insufficient, but women can play their parts.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I like it, 'twill be new.

lg.l: We will not present it to the Princess
But engage her person in the action,
We shall be too few else, some pretty interlude
To square with our number — d'ye allow it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Come 'I'll acquaint you with a plot, then instantly: refer yourselves to me for your parts, we can receive no disparagement, our spectators cannot jeer us, for we'll speak but to the people in the hangings, and they have as much judgement, as some men that are but clothes, at most, but walking pictures.

sp.speaker: Fide.
sp.p: I shall be on't.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: What part will you give me, I'll be a King.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Thou'lt play a tyrant bravely.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'll fit you all I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Now our invisible merchant is caged, we may redeem our opinion and pass again in the rank of discrete courtiers.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: I think now to most of the beholders, he is invisible all but his head, for he has but a small grate to look out at.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He shall gull no more with his art I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Nay, he is like to lie by't, for I hear since, all his creditors, like so many crows have light upon him, and they'll leave him but a thin carcase.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Let 'em pick out his eyes, what care we.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He sent me an epistle to take pity on him.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But I hope thou hast more wit than to show thyself a christian to such a rascal as he is.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p:
I returned him my court compliment, that I was sorry I could not serve him: I would do him any office that stretched not to mine own prejudice, that
we had taken order with his keeper; upon payment of our sums disbursed, he might be enlarged.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Which is impossible.

Prithee let me see his letter, in what submissive language the rogue does beseech us, — most heroic signiors, — good — I throw myself at the feet of your mercy, for to your justice, I beg I may not be made a sacrifice — nay, we'll make him beg ere we ha' done.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: At the grate.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I confess I ha' done you wrong — does he so? it shall not serve the turn — there is no hope I shall ever satisfy you, — all the better, lie and rot — if I be known a prisoner to my creditors, I am irrecoverably lost, o compassionate, a miserable man, who otherwise must soon forfeit his day light, and die in a dungeon. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Save you noble signiors. —

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: — Ha.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: ▪ 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Did he not die in prison, and his ghost haunts us, brave! — 'tis not he.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: When this eternal substance of my soul, did live imprisoned in my wanton flesh, and so forth? and how d'ye like don Andrea gentlemen; poor snake, but he has cast his skin, and recovered a new coat oth' destinies spinning. The bird is flown again.

sp.speaker: Don
sp.p: How the devil came he at liberty.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: And thus gallant.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: The slave does not beg of your heroic signiorship, a court ▪ compassion, debts must be paid, there is no danger of the grate as the case goes, nor of forfeiting his daylight in a dungeon, if I mistake not, my illustrious pair of widgens, my serene smooth-faced coxcombs, whose brains are curdled this hot weather: will your neat worship sell your cloak, ha? or you that superfluous double hatched rapier, there be sums in nature to lend you, upon security that I shall like of.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He jeers us.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Would we durst beat him.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You see me now gentlemen perfectly, what if I should walk before you without a body, my head hanging in the air like a comet.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Would thou were't hanged any way.

lg.l: Here's Rolliardo too.
Let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Or shall I appoint you a day when I will be invisible all but my hand?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: No, I thank you sir, we have some business at this present.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Let's to the prison, and know the wonder better — noble signior.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: For your crowns.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: We are glad we had 'em for you, dear signior talk no more on 'em,

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Farewell phantasmas then — ha? 'tis he, sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Keep your way.

lg.l: You do not know me
But I ha' brought a life which by your means
Has been preserved from wretchedness, your bounty,
Deserves you should dispose it.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: What are you.

lg.l: I was the object of a charity
We seldom meet in mankind, from a prison
You sent a sum to free me.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Prithee friend, if thou'st received a benefit, go home, and say thy prayers: — I would forget it.

lg.l: Among many whom your nobleness enlarged,
I came to make you tender of my service:
Despise not sir my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: D'ye mock me?

lg.l: May my soul want heaven's mercy then: to you,
Next my creator, I do owe my this being
I have a soul is full of thanks, but name
Employment to assure you, and you make me twice happy.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: I ha' nothing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Then I ha' something to say to you.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: How.

lg.l: And you shall hear it too, and give me thanks
You've sowed your charity in a fruitful ground,
Which shall return it tenfold; nay one hundred.
What you have done for me you shall acknowledge
I will deserve toth' height.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Thou'rt liberal in language.

lg.l: I'll be active — off with this sullen face,
It scurvily 'Becomes you, d'ye hear.
I studied for you, since you paid my debts,
I'll do you a courtesy and save your life,
Which your attempt upon the Princess has
Left desperate, a happy fancy sir,
If heaven will please to prosper it, and you
Not be your own enemy to refuse it.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what meanest?

lg.l: Nay you shall laugh and heartily ere I ha' done w'e
The Duke does love his daughter, sends her all
Rarities are presented to him.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: His soul's not dearer to him — what of that?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Why then you shall be admitted into the castle of comfort, that's all; the conceit is in my brain, and would you could as probably get her consent, to untie her virgin zone, as I dispose your access to her: it shall not cost you much, if I fail, instead of saying of my prayers, I'll curse the destinies and die with you.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: D'ye hear, I ha' bestowed 300. Crowns already to set your heels at liberty, if you do mock me, it shall cost me 500. but I'll ha' ▪ you clapped up again, where you shall howl all day at the grate, for a meal at night from the basket.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: You are in earnest now?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: By all that you have threatened, so am I, have but the patience to walk and hear me.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Can thy art procure this?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: My art? Why look you, I made this watch. I'll bestow it on you.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: What to do? to reckon the hours I ha' to live.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: It shall not cost me so much trouble as that toy did to make you master of your wishes, still if heaven prosper it: come let's talk privately, you shall ha' the plot.

lg.l: He that doth many good deeds it may fall,
Among the rest, one may reward them all.
I long to be discoursing it, pray lead the way.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.p: Provide again you mock me not — come on sir.

div.head: Scaena, i.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Rollyardo pay his debts? Sure the fellow that never saw much money in's life, now by the Duke made master of so many sums, is grown mad with 'em.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Many other he hath discharged they say.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: He'll undo the exchequer, and he hold on, he shall be chronicled for't.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He has some cause to imagine himself short lived, and that makes him so desperately charitable, towards his end. Signior Perenotto.

sp.speaker: Peren.
sp.p: Dondolo and Grutti, news, news for ye.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What we beseech you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You have lost the best mirth in Italy in your absence, your companion Morello —

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Was carried to the Duke in a petticoat, in which he attempted a passage to the sequestered ladies — what's the issue.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Mirth in abundance.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: How came he off?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Nay 'tis on still, the Duke to make himself sport, would call a counsel, before whom the poor signior
must be arraigned; not to hold you in circumstance, the business was merrily discussed, and the pitiful projector was judged —

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: How, how?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To wear the petticoat for a month, if he appear without it during the term, he incurs his perpetual exile from court.

sp.speaker: Don. Gru.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You may imagine with what variety of lamentable faces, the courtier heard his unexpected sentence, some would have pleaded for him but for laughter, which continued so long and so high, that he had time to collect his scattered senses, and instead of swooning, which was expected, he grew fortified, and most humbly besought the Duke, since his sentence had passed so definitive, he would be so merciful, to admit him that course of a moon to be his jester, that since he could not shake off the fool's coat, that he might have that favourable pretence to keep it on.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Very good —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Twas easily granted, but ever since, to the astonishment of the hearers, he is grown so ▪ jocund and airy, nay as if he had been born with a song in's head, he talks everlasting ballad, no man laughs at him but he lashes him in rhyme worse than a satyr, the Duke has privileged his mirth, made him fool-free, and now he plays the tyrant — he's here already.

lg.l: Oyes, oh yes, oh yes,
If there be any one in city or in town
Can show me a wise man I'll please him for his pain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Disgrace has made him witty.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What will you say to him, will show you a wise man?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Marry if he go far, he is not so wise as he should be. Dondolo, Grutti! Old acquaintance how is't? How is't?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: The case is altered with you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It does appear so, but nothing can make me proud, I'll know my fellows.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How do you mean Morello?

lg.l: Your lordship may make one at football,
▪ 'tis all the sport nowadays .
What other is the world then a ball,
Which we run after with whoop and with hollow,
He that doth catch it is sure of a fall,
His heels tripped up by him that doth follow.

sp.speaker: Dond.
sp.p: Do not women play too?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: They are too light, quickly down.

sp.speaker: Mor.

lg.l: Oyes, they are the best gamesters of all,
